definition: Lü Dongbin (796-), Tang Dynasty scholar, one of the Eight Immortals 八仙[Ba1 xian1]
pitchpipe, pitch standard, one of the twelve semitones in the traditional tone system
surname Lü
cave/hole/zero (unambiguous spoken form when spelling out numbers)/CL:個|个[ge4]
visitor/guest/object (in grammar)
a dog biting Lü Dongbin (idiom)/to ill reward a person's kindness
pinyin: gou3 yao3 Lu:3 Dong4 bin1 , bu4 shi2 hao3 ren2 xin1
containing_words.word: 狗咬呂洞賓，不識好人心

sentences.english: Legend has it that once Lü's home caught fire.
sentences.chinese: 傳說呂洞賓家有一次失火。

sentences.english: It must be that Lü Dongbin's pet dog bit him.
sentences.chinese: 肯定是呂洞賓的愛犬咬了他一口。

sentences.english: One of Lu Dongbin's powers is to cause couples to break up.
sentences.chinese: 呂洞賓的神力之一是讓情侶分手。

definition: popular tradition/folk legend
founding master of a monastery/founder/originator

Chen Tuan (871-989), a legendary Daoist sage
Liuying township in Tainan county 台南縣|台南县[Tai2 nan2 xian4], Taiwan
Wu Cheng'en (1500-1582), author (or compiler) of novel Journey to the West 西遊記|西游记
Nagarjuna (Nagarjuna Bodhisattva)
Nāgārjuna (c. 150-250 AD), Buddhist philosopher
ancestral hall/temple to one's forebears
variant of 圖像|图像[tu2 xiang4]
celestial troops and generals (idiom)/fig. superior forces
elegant name/honorific
Wuying district of Yichun city 伊春市[Yi1 chun1 shi4], Heilongjiang
Jianzhen or Ganjin (688-763), Tang dynastic Buddhist monk, who crossed to Japan after several unsuccessful attempts, influential in Japanese Buddhism
scripture hall (Buddhism)
Mt Meru or Sumeru, sacred mountain in Buddhist and Jain tradition/Mt Xumi in Guyuan 固原[Gu4 yuan2], Ningxia, with many Buddhist cave statues
